title: More of a Football news source rather than much to do about Fantasy Football
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2015
content: This is an Echo front end to the Fantasy Football Nerd website. This uses "Nerd Rank" technology to crowd source ratings. They're good enough to be quotes as "the Cliffs Notes of the Industry" by The Washington Post in 2009.Ease of Use: 3 out of 5. It's pretty simple, you can just ask for news, or about a certain player. It was better than I expected with the player names. It did crash once, but it got all the others I tried right. When it reads the general news, it is in several segments. It can get kind of long. It would have been nice if it was split up and you could cycle through them conversationally. Player news is also in segments, but the gap between them is less clear. This can create some confusion as one news update runs into the next. Also, the text comes straight from their site, and occasionally it reads web-links, which is confusing and unhelpful.Usefulness: 3 out of 5. I know almost nothing about Fantasy Football. But this skill seems more of a Football news source rather than much to do about Fantasy Football. That's great for football fans. I don't know how great that is for Fantasy Football fans. Perhaps it should have been marketed more towards mainstream football enthusiasts.Novelty: 3 out of 5. It's another "read the news to  you" skill. The news appears to be high quality and relevant for the topic. But it really is just about the news.Overall: 3 out of 5. It's fairly specific in it's appeal, although, admittedly, football is rather popular. I'd like to see them add in more interaction and connect with the gameplay of Fantasy Football itself. There are several tools on the web site and I think the skill will improve greatly if they integrate those in going forward.

How can I give that game one of those new features like that? I don’t know how. also, for the opposing team, the echo just keeps using the same names over and over again. I don’t like that. title: Needs a better quality audio clip
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2018
content: As this app does only one thing, it really should be better. I had music playing, which appropriately muted and Alexa said, “Let’s call those Hogs!,” which was actually very muddled, but I could overlook that part had the call been better. It was probably 5 notches quieter on the volume control than what I had been listening to, and I had to strain to hear it. I have my Echo Spot connected to a [very high quality] speaker (apparently we cannot use other brand names in reviews), so sufficed to say, it wasn’t the sub quality mono speaker at fault. It sounded like someone just had their tv on, recorded it on their phone from across the room, then posted it as an Alexa skill. I mean, if you’re going to post it, I’m sure UA would provide you an HD or UHD audio clip, or even better would be a video clip. That way you get to witness the spectacle of Razorback Nation as well as actually hearing it clearly. But that’s just a suggestion. At the very least, you could have a Razorback on my screen. I do like that I don’t need to stop my other skill to use it. I could be listening to the game, a commercial break comes along and I could just have an impromptu hog call-which sometimes happens!

title: My Favorite Wrestling Podcast
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2019
content: I love this guy. Jon is like the the best friend who gets just a glimpse behind the curtain. He is knowledgeable about current wrestling stars and promotions. I laugh with him, not at him when he completely mispronounces  names of 70s and 80s stars. I get it. I used to work in broadcasting. Trust me it is not easy. What impresses me most is he is does an entertaining show on many platforms. He works alone, no sponsors. He is not in a WWE Studio, he is probably using his own equipment. Also, he isn't in some wrestling mecca like Stamford, or Louisville, or Winter Park. He's is in that wonderful place called Hazzard, Kentucky.  Still i put his show up there against the big boys who have producers, writers, and staff, that make their shows so polished.

title: Best wrestling news aggregate - Jammin John is the man
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2018
content: Incredibly informative and incredibly sincere. Jammin John rattles off every possible piece of news, rumors, injury updates, promotion schedules, the business side of the business...absolutely everything. Instead of spending an hour googling to find all this info scattered about the internet, listen to John - he’s doing it for you. And it’s straight information, too - no injected opinions. The only time subjectivity creeps in is in his sincere well wishes of speedy recovery to injured talent. And I just like the guy. Its obvious he’s a genuine fan and loves and respects the business. Jammin John is the man.

title: Great Briefing
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
content: Jammin Jon is really fun to listen to. He gives great wrestling news and is really caring about his community. I really enjoy this daily briefing.

title: I just want wrestling news...
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2019
content: I WAS enjoying this app and tolerated all the frequent and lengthy (often longer than the actual news portion) non-wrestling commentary, about everything other than wrestling. But I've finally reached my threshold. The final straw came when Jon detailed all the information relating to his wisdom tooth ordeal. I'm really sympathetic and I'm glad everything worked out in the end, but a program about wrestling news isn't the place for a looong, detailed description about an infection complete with descriptive visuals (ie "puss"). I listen to my Echo news briefings in the AM while eating breakfast. No one wants to hear about puss and infection while eating. No thanks. If you want wrestling news in a nice condensed format on your Echo, look elsewhere.

title: Solid recaps bogged down by biases/inconsistancies
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2021
content: When Jon is actually giving the news, he does a very solid job. His personal stories do come off as cries for sympathy sometimes, but we all deal with our tribulations in different ways. I’m not going to fault him for that, and sometimes it does make you feel like you know him. Your call if you mind that or not.Lately, though biases have been glaring with fave wrestling promotions and even his politics. We all have our biases so no worries. But his reviews of individual matches dont add up in his reviews of events as a whole. One promotion gets crapped on (politely) while others are overpraised based on his own reviews. Then his politics bleed into show reviews too.I subscribed for the last few years, but I’m looking for an alternative now.

skillname: Sports News Minute Flash Briefing and Daily Update
title: Sports news update is here!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2021
content: UPDATED: The negative reviews about the feed playing old episode is no longer happening.I have searched and searched for a good sports news podcast that is not 30 minutes long. If you’d like to get your news from podcasts this is the podcast to add to your lineup.Every morning I get five minute news clips from a variety of sources: national news, political news, kick off the day news… there are lots of options there. But for sports there are not. Larry Brown is fulfilling that need.If you like to get your news from podcasts, then add Larry Brown to your lineup. In around one minute or so he gives you the highlights that’s going on in the sports world. He doesn’t go into depth but he let you know what’s going on so if you want more info, go search for it on the net.If you want exclusive scores for your teams, add that specific skill so you can say “Alexa what’s my my sports update”?Larry, thank you for offering great sports news!

title: On a crisp Southern California afternoon in my office overlooking ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2018
content: On a crisp Southern California afternoon in my office overlooking the vast landscape of Orange County leading off to the Sierra Nevadas in the distance. I stood by my window deep in thought as the sun continued it's descent toward the horizon. Then the thought struck me, "When do my Anteaters have their next baseball game?". I turned to Alexa and within a matter of seconds she had me fully updated on all the UCI baseball details I desired.

title: CNN is stale, NPR and Fox do not stop when flash briefing is complete!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
content: One of our most used skills is Alex's Flash Briefing, but it has become irksome.  We select NPR for the Flash briefing skill because the CNN Flash Briefing is almost worthless -- apparently CNN only updates it once a day.  Unfortunately, the NPR briefing does not stop when the flash briefing is complete, but continues into boring, biased commentary.  Curiously, when we tell Alexa to stop the skill, the device almost never accepts the first command, and continues to babble on.  BTW, the Fox News selection for the skill does exactly the same thing.Amazon, please fix this behavior!  We are all-in on Echo, with four Shows and numerous audio Echos, but I would consider adding a Google device just to get a proper news briefing.

title: Madenning Madness
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2018
content: Alexa is confused even by the name of the skill. She insists there is no March Madness available. After arguing with her for some time, Alexa finally concedes. Win for me! At last a live game begins playing. I try to switch between games, and Alexa decides there are no other games. I beg. I plead. She becomes stubborn and opts for music instead. I immediately demand March Madness. With evil in her voice, Alexa taunts me, saying there is no such skill.  We begin the process all over again...Yes, I've discovered the true meaning of March Madness!?!

title: Silence after it says it will play game
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
content: I just wanted to listen live... Alexa welcomes you and tells you that's an option when you say "open march madness" (that's critical to even get started) but, alas, finally confirming what game (after much trial and error) results in silence. She says "playing UCSB vs. Creighton" (the game I currently wanted to tune into) and then nothing happens. Tried again, same outcome. Offering this app, telling us it let us listen live, then not delivering is worse than no app at all. Waste of time.

title: It works, finally!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2020
content: this skill has been unavailable forever. ive had better luck just using team names alone - not the formal name. like “alexa, ask mlb to play the twins game” -(not MINNESOTA TWINS) my only complaint im not sure where blame goes?  to me, the audio is so low, if i flip over to the televised game, i have to remember to turn my volume way down.  not only that but a lot of the broadcasts sound like the audio was recorded on a sony walkman. but it works! dont forget to turn cellular on if you use it w wifi mostly. itll hook up to car stereo w no issues.  great job, dev team! thanks

title: needs improvement
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2021
content: the app is so spotty and and a bit pushy. the data is often stale. for example, there is a game in process and it gives me the score from the previous game. it tends to seize control of alexa; you have to tell it in several different way to JUST STOP. bad app for a a multi billion $ sport and an even bigger retailer, Amazon. i did notice you have to buy audio separatrly, even if you have season subscription for televised games. if you ate going to squuze every penny possible from consumers, the app should be much better, intuitive and less intrusive.

title: Instructions ambiguous
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2020
content: The narrative wanders and is weak, has inane encouragment (it's a flipping machine!)  and fails to prepare you for the next exercise, and is ambiguous about start time.  How about 1) advanced warning of next exercise, 2) clear, uniform starting narrative, 3) clear, uniform ending narrative?  Then rinse and repeat.  EVERY exercise should be like1) "Prepare for Jumping Jacks"2) "Start Jumping Jacks in 5,4,3,2,1 START!"3) "Continue jumping jacks for 5,4,3,2,1, STOP, and rest for 15 seconds"4) "Prepare for next exercise: forward lunges"5) "Start forward lunges in 5,4,3,2,1 START!"and so forth.So every exercise has a "get ready" notice 10 seconds in advance.Every exercise is started with a countdown and "START!", no exceptionsEvery exercise is started with a countdown and "STOP"!, no exceptionsOther narrative "Great job! Keep going!" I find silly, distracting, and counterproductive.  This is a fancy timer to do a very focused workout. If it did only that, it would be terrific.  The encouragement (by an electronic device that has no idea if you've done the exercise well!) is a negative and there's no way to make it a positive.

title: Interesting idea...but could be a lot better
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2017
content: I like the idea of having an Alexa skill help you figure out what to wear for a run. And this skill does do that...after some work. You basically have to tell it everything--eg male/female, temperature, kind of run, etc. and then it gives you a canned recommendation, which isn't bad. The only thing that would be really cool is if it could remember your stats, and if it could incorporate a live weather feed so that you don't have to tell it that. For example, "Alexa, ask running outfit advisor for a recommendation for Mark in Denver Colorado today at 2pm". If it could remember that Mark is a male and look up the weather, that would be very cool. This is a great idea that could/should be built upon. Nice start!
